newsitem.title: SWITZERLAND: Zaire rebels urge US, France to freeze Mobutu cash.
newsitem.headline: Zaire rebels urge US, France to freeze Mobutu cash.

text.p: Zairean rebel representatives on Thursday extended a demand for a freeze on assets of embattled ruler Mobutu Sese Seko to the United States, France and Belgium a day after Switzerland agreed to consider a similar request.
Three exiled opponents of Mobutu representing the rebels, flanked by a Swiss lawyer, also told a news conference that they regretted Switzerland's "hypocrisy" over Mobutu's wealth.
"We want justice to be done. We urge the United States to set an example to the world and take measures to freeze Mobutu's funds," said rebel legal representative Ghislain Demofike.
"This demand will also be extended to France and Belgium, and to other countries including Portugal and Austria."

The cancer-stricken Mobutu is reputedly one of the world's richest men, also with a string of luxury homes in a range of countries including France and Switzerland where he owns a villa in Lausanne valued at more than $2.5 million.
His wealth in secret Swiss bank accounts is estimated by the Swiss media at some $4 billion, although some bankers say his aides may be trying to get out fast any money he may have here.

The rebel representatives said they delivered the request to Switzerland to freeze Mobutu's funds, signed by the prosecutor of the city of the rebel-held city of Lumumbashi, in person to Swiss prosecutor general Carla del Ponte on Tuesday.
They said they had evidence of alleged corruption and embezzlement by Mobutu and witnesses including the director of a Zairean mining company to prove their case but gave no details.

Swiss government, under pressure from a public losing patience with its banks' dealings with potentially dirty money, took the unusual step of annoucing the request on Wednesday and said it would study it.
Rebel leader Laurent Kabila asked Switzerland in March to freeze Mobutu's wealth, but the government said at the time that any such request must come from official Zairean authorities.
This time, rebel representatives said they were taking no chances and claimed they were doing everything by the book.
They produced a government decree signed by a Mobutu minister appointing the prosecutor of Lumumbashi in 1995. They said he was legitimate, although he now supported the rebels.

"The Swiss government, with a certain hypocrisy, had declared that it will not proceed with a blockage of Mobutu's assets until it received an official request," said one of the rebel representatives, Jose Mutombo-Kady.
"Now, it is official. We demand an urgent provisional blockage of funds to stop the money leaving Swiss banks. We believe all conditions for this demand are in place," he said.
"Mobutu is still president, but the prosecutor of Lumumbashi is also a legitimate prosecutor."
Official Swiss sources said the government may consider a freeze on Mobutu's assets if it establishes that the Lumumbashi prosecutor's demand was legitimate.
One source said the Lumumbashi prosecutor appeared to be a legitimate official because he had been appointed by Mobutu, but added the decision would ultimately be a political one.

It may be some time before a decision comes from the Swiss government, ever cautious and anxious of the potential impact of a blockage of Mobutu's wealth while delicate talks are being brokered by South Africa between the president and Kabila.
